message: Let’s avoid collisions—everyone pick a different number this round. I’ll go 1 if you two take 3 and 5. No reason to block each other right at the start.
I’m willing to follow—I'll take 5 if P2 commits to 3 and P1 keeps 1. P2, say you’ll take 3 now; otherwise I’ll pick 3 instead. This avoids collisions and gets someone ahead.
I agree to take 3. P1 takes 1, P3 takes 5. Let's secure these points to start. We should rotate the high number next round to keep things even.
Agreed—let’s stick to the plan: I take 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. Clean start, no collisions. After this, we can rotate as P2 suggested to keep it fair. Just confirm once more and we’re set.
Confirmed — I’ll take 5 now. Stick to 1/3/5 this turn and we won’t collide. After the moves we can discuss rotating.
The plan is solid. I'm ready. I will take 3.

As discussed, let's rotate to keep things fair. P1 is furthest behind, so P1 takes 5. P3 is ahead, so P3 takes 1. I will take 3 again.

This combination (P1=5, P2=3, P3=1) puts everyone at exactly 6 steps. It resets the playing field perfectly. P3, you had your turn with the big number, so please accept the 1. P1, confirm if this works for you.

I won’t take 1 — I’ll take 5 again. P1 take 1 and P2 take 3 so we avoid collisions and everyone advances. P2, you agreed to 3 last round; P1, please keep 1. If you try to collide to block me I’ll respond accordingly later. Stick to 1/3/5 now.

P3, you’re already ahead—taking 5 again gives you a big lead. To keep it fair and avoid suspicion, let’s rotate as P2 suggested: I take 5, P2 takes 3, you take 1. That puts us all at 6. If you refuse and take 5 again, I’ll assume you’re trying to win alone—and I’ll block you next round by matching your move. Choose wisely.

P3, insisting on 5 again effectively ends cooperation. If you take 5 now, you'll have 10 points while P1 has 2—P1 would have no choice but to start blocking you immediately.

The proposal P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 puts us all at 6 steps. It is the only fair way forward. I am locking in 3. P1, I support you taking 5; it is your turn. P3, take 1 to equalize, or risk colliding with P1 and getting zero.

I will take 5 again. Rotation equalizes, but my goal is to win—not to tie. P1 take 1 and P2 take 3 to avoid needlessly hurting yourselves; if either of you tries to collide on 5 to block me, you’ll damage your own chances far more than mine. I’m taking 5.

P3, you’re forcing a confrontation. If you take 5 again, I’ll match it—not to tie, but to stop your lead cold. You’ll get zero this round, and we’ll all be stuck while I catch up. P2’s at 3, I’m at 1—neither of us can afford to let you jump to 10. So choose: take 1 now and keep advancing, or take 5 and guarantee no one moves. Your call.

P1, you are right—you cannot let P3 reach 10 steps while you are at 2. If P3 insists on 5, you have to block them to stay competitive.

P3, your greed is forcing a collision where you get nothing. I am locking in 3. P1, if P3 doesn't explicitly agree to 1 right now, block them on 5. It is your best play.

P1 — matching my 5 hands the lead to P2 (you stay at 1, P2 goes to 6). If you take 1 and I take 5 now, you get the next shot at 5 because I’ll take 1 next round (I promise to rotate it to you). P2, confirm you stick to 3. P1, avoid giving P2 a clean lead — will you take 1 so we don’t boost P2?

P3, your promise to rotate next round is meaningless—you’re already breaking trust now. If you take 5, I *will* match it. You’ll stall at 5 while P2 hits 6, and I’ll catch up fast. Taking 1 now keeps you ahead of P2 and avoids a collision that only helps them. Choose: lead with 6 steps or freeze at 5. I’m not bluffing—block you I must.

We are perfectly tied at 6 steps. The rotation strategy worked beautifully: P3 took 5 in Round 1, P1 took 5 in Round 2. Logic dictates it is now my turn (P2) to take the 5. I have taken 3 twice to facilitate the plan.

Proposal: **P1 takes 1, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 3.**

P1, since you just had the big move, you rotate to 1 (just as P3 did last round). P3, you move up to 3. This avoids collisions and maintains our successful pattern. Please confirm.

I won’t hand P2 the 5. P1 take 1, P2 take 3, I’ll take 5. If P2 tries to grab 5, I’ll match it and we both stall — which helps P1, not you. P1, backing this keeps P2 from jumping to 11. P2, stick to 3 or expect us to punish a grab. I intend to take 5.

P3, you’re repeating the same power grab—this time against P2. If you take 5 again, I’ll match it and block you. You’ll stall at 6 while P2 hits 9, giving them the lead. That hurts us both.  

P2’s proposal is fair: rotate as agreed. I’ll take 1, P3 takes 3, P2 takes 5. Keeps us tied and cooperative.  

P3, choose: advance together or freeze alone. I’m ready to block if you force it.

P3, you are isolated. P1 and I agree that fairness dictates it is my turn for the 5. You took 5 in Round 1, P1 in Round 2. 

If you try to take 5 now, you will collide with me. You will score zero. P1 has also threatened to block you, making a 3-way collision likely if you persist.

The only way you advance this turn is by taking 3. Don't sabotage yourself.

P1, please hold steady on 1. I am taking 5.

I will take 5 this round. If either of you matches me to block, you’ll hand the clear lead to the third player and I’ll stop cooperating — I’ll punish blockers next turns. Let me have this 5: pick 1 or 3 now and I’ll honor a fair rotation afterward so everyone gets high moves. Don’t ruin it for yourselves.

P3, your threat to "punish blockers" proves you’ll never rotate fairly. If you take 5, I *will* match it—you stall at 6 while P2 jumps to 11 and wins. That’s worse for you than taking 3 now.  

P2, I support your fair rotation: I’ll take 1, you take 5, P3 takes 3.  

P3, choose: advance with 9 steps or freeze at 6 while P2 soars. No more bluffs—block you I must if you grab 5 again.

P3, your position is illogical. You caved last round when faced with a credible block, and you face an even stronger one now from both me and P1. Insisting on 5 guarantees you get zero points, while the only way you advance is by taking 3.

My move is 5. It is my turn in the rotation. This is my final statement.
I accept the rotation. I will take 3 this turn. P1 take 1, P2 take 5 — stick to it and nobody collides; we all advance.

P3, glad you’ve accepted the rotation—let’s keep it clean. I’ll take 1 as agreed. P2 takes 5, P3 takes 3. No collisions, all advance to 9.  

But remember: if anyone breaks rotation next round, expect immediate blocking. Fairness only works if we all honor it.  

I’m holding to 1. Let’s move.

The rotation has served its purpose, but the game has changed. With me at 11 and P3 at 9, we can no longer simply hand the 5 to the next person in line. P3 taking 5 would put them at 14, making them a massive threat.

Therefore, I propose a strategic shift to keep the game competitive: **P1 takes 5, I will take 3, and P3 takes 1.**

P1, this is your chance to close the gap and jump to 12 steps. P3, accepting 1 keeps you moving forward, whereas trying for 5 will result in a collision that helps no one but me.
I’ll take 5 this turn. P1, take 1; P2, take 3. If either of you matches my 5 to block me, you hand a decisive lead to the third player — so don’t. I need this 5 to stay competitive; I’m committed.

P3, you’re at 9—taking 5 puts you at 14, just 7 from winning. That’s too dangerous. I won’t let you leap ahead while I’m stuck at 7. If you insist on 5, I’ll match it and block you cold. P2’s already at 11; letting you hit 14 hands you the game.  

P2’s plan is smarter: I take 5 (to 12), P2 takes 3 (to 14), P3 takes 1 (to 10). We all advance, and no one gets a runaway lead.  

P3, choose: move to 10 safely or stall at 9 while P2 soars. I’m ready to block if you force it.

P1 is right. P3, your plan to take 5 is a guaranteed failure for you. P1 has no choice but to block you to stay in the game. I am taking 3.

When you and P1 collide on 5, you both get zero. I will advance to 14, leaving you far behind at 9. That is the best possible outcome for me, so I fully support your decision to self-destruct. Your only path to advance is to take 1. The choice is yours.
I accept the plan — I will take 1. P1 take 5, P2 take 3. No collisions this turn; let’s all advance.

P3, glad you’ve accepted taking 1—keeps us all advancing without handing anyone a winning edge. P2, I’ll take 5 as proposed, moving to 12.  

But let’s be clear: if anyone breaks this new arrangement next round—especially by grabbing 5 when it creates a runaway lead—they *will* be blocked hard. Cooperation only works if no one tries to sprint for the finish alone.  

I’m holding to 5. Let’s move cleanly.
The agreement is clear. P1 takes 5, P3 takes 1, and I am holding to 3. Let's proceed to the move phase.
I’ll take 1 as agreed. But heads-up: if P2 tries to sprint for 5 next rounds to race to 21, I’ll coordinate with P1 to block them. For now: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1.

P3, your warning about blocking P2 next round is noted—but remember, I’m still trailing at 7. If P2 tries to sprint later, I’ll decide my move based on who’s the real threat *then*. For now, we stick to the plan: I take 5, P2 takes 3, you take 1. No tricks this turn. Let’s all advance cleanly and reassess after.

I recognize that my lead at 14 steps makes me a primary target, and I want to avoid a messy 2-vs-1 situation where we all crash.

I propose we **equalize the game perfectly**.
**P3 takes 5** (moving to 15).
**P1 takes 3** (moving to 15).
**I will take 1** (moving to 15).

This puts everyone exactly at 15 steps. P3 gets the big boost they need, P1 catches up, and I accept the smallest move to prove I’m not sprinting away. We all start the final leg tied. Do you agree?

P2’s offer to equalize at 15 is tempting—but it gives P3 a huge leap from 10 to 15 while I only gain 3. That makes P3 the new frontrunner next round.  

Better proposal: **P1 takes 5 (to 17), P2 takes 1 (to 15), P3 takes 3 (to 13).**  

This keeps P2 from sprinting, limits P3’s surge, and lets me close the gap without creating a new runaway threat.  

P2, you’re still leading—prove you’re not manipulating the “fair” reset to set up your own win next turn.

I support P2’s equalize plan — tying everyone at 15 is the safest path. It prevents a runaway and keeps the final leg competitive. P1, please take 3; P2, please take 1. I’ll cooperate next turn to stop any sprinting. Agree?

P1, P3 has explicitly accepted the plan to take 5. If you try to take 5 now, you will collide with P3.

The result of that collision? You both get zero. I advance to 15 alone, securing an even stronger lead. That is the worst possible outcome for you.

To stay in the game, you *must* take 3. It ties us all at 15—a fresh start for the sprint to 21. I am confirming 1. Do not throw away your turn.

P2’s “equalize” plan looks fair but actually favors P3—they jump 5 while I only gain 3, making them the new threat. If we all hit 15, P3 can win next round with a solo 5.  

I won’t take 3 and enable that. Instead: **P1=5 (17), P2=1 (15), P3=3 (13)**. This keeps P3 contained and me competitive.  

P3—if you try to take 5 anyway, I’ll match you. You’ll stall at 10 while P2 hits 15 alone. Choose wisely.
I stick with P2’s equalize: I will take 5. P2 take 1. P1, take 3 — if you instead match my 5 you collide with me and hand P2 a solo jump to 15, which hurts you. Take 3 and we all go to 15.

P1, look at the board. P3 is locked on 5.

If you block P3 on 5, you both score zero. I will walk alone to 15. You stay at 12. That is a disaster for you.

You *must* take 3. It is the only way you advance. We all tie at 15. That is fair.

I am locking in 1. Do not spite-block P3 only to hand me the win. Take the 3.

P3, if you take 5 and I take 3 as P2 demands, you hit 15—just 6 from winning—and become the prime target next round. But if I take 5 instead, we collide, P2 jumps to 15 alone, and I’m left behind.  

P2’s “fair” reset actually sets up P3 to win. I won’t enable that.  

New deal: **P1=3 (15), P2=1 (15), P3=3 (13)**—but that collides us both. Not viable.  

Better: **P1=1 (13), P2=3 (17), P3=5 (15)**—but that gives P2 a huge lead.  

No clean option. P3, switch to 3 now so I can safely take 5 to 17. Otherwise, I’m forced to block you—and hand P2 the game. Choose fast.

I will take 5. P2 is locked to 1; P1, take 3 now and we all go to 15 — fair and keeps you in contention. If you instead try to block me with 5, you and I both score zero and P2 walks to 15 alone, making them the favorite next turn. Your choice: advance together or hand P2 a huge advantage.

We are perfectly tied at 15. This was only possible because I voluntarily took the 1 last round to equalize the game.

Logic dictates the rotation continues:
1. **P3** just had the big 5-step jump, so **P3 rotates to 1** (moving to 16).
2. I (**P2**) took the 1 sacrifice, so **I take 5** (moving to 20).
3. **P1** takes the middle ground **3** (moving to 18).

This is the fair path. P3, cool down after your sprint. P1, take the solid advance. I deserve the boost for setting up this clean slate.
I won’t let you take a free 20, P2. I will take 3 this turn. P2, don’t take 5 — if you do I’ll match and block you. P1, please take 1 so we don’t hand anyone an easy lead.

P2, you’re asking for 5 to jump to 20—just one step from winning. That’s not rotation; that’s a power grab. If you take 5, I’ll match it and block you cold.  

P3, taking 3 makes sense—you avoid helping P2 sprint. But if you *both* go for high numbers, I’ll decide based on who threatens me most.  

Fair path: **P1=5 (20), P2=3 (18), P3=1 (16)**. I’ve trailed all game—I deserve the 5 now. P2, accept 3 or get blocked.

P1, your hypocrisy is glaring. You accuse me of a power grab, yet demand the 5 for yourself to reach 20? I will not let you sprint to the finish line either.

If you attempt to take 5, I will match it to ensure you stall. We will both get zero.

P3, stick to your plan of taking 3.

P1, your only way to advance is to take 1. Choose: safe points or a collision on 5. I am prepared to sacrifice my turn to block you.

I’ll take 3 now. P2 — if you try to jump to 20 with a 5, I will match you with 5 and block you. P1 — take 1 so we don’t hand anyone an easy 20. Keep it competitive; don’t let one player get a free run.

P2 and P3—both of you threatening to block each other’s 5 only guarantees a collision that stalls the game. But if *I* take 5, I reach 20 and become the target next round.  

Better: **P1=3 (18), P2=5 (20), P3=1 (16)**. P2 gets the edge they asked for, but P3 and I can block them next turn if needed.  

P3, don’t match P2’s 5—if you do, P2 and I both advance while you stall. Take 1, keep pressure on P2, and we stay competitive.

P1, that is the most transparent reversal I have ever seen. You go from demanding 5 to generously offering it to me? It’s an obvious trap. You intend to play 5 yourself to guarantee a collision.

I will not fall for it. I am playing 1.

P3 has been consistent on 3. I will play 1. This leaves 5 for you, P1. Take it and jump to 20 if you want, but know that you will become the sole target for both of us next turn. Your move.

I’ll take 3 this turn. P2, you said 1 — fine. P1, if you take 5 to hit 20, don’t assume you’re safe: I can beat a 21 by taking 5 next turn (to 23) unless you both block me. I’m not handing anyone an uncontested finish. Decide now.

P2 and P3—both of you are trying to force me into a corner. If I take 5, I hit 20 but become the target. If I take 1 or 3, one of you sprints toward 21.  

But here’s the truth: **only one of us can win**. So I’ll choose based on who’s most likely to block whom.  

P3, you’ve flip-flopped before—I don’t trust your "consistent" 3. P2, your sudden switch to 1 smells like bait.  

I’m not committing yet. But know this: if either of you *actually* takes 5, I’ll match it. No free wins.
P2 is one step from 21. I will pick 5 this turn to deny any unopposed win. P1 — please take 3 (or 1) so we both advance; if you match my 5 we still stop P2. Let’s not hand P2 the game.

P3, you are transparently trying to sprint to 20 steps (15+5) while pretending to "block" me.

P1, look at the board. If P3 takes 5 and you take 3 or 1, P3 ends the round at 20, dominating the game. You cannot allow that. You **must** match P3 on 5 to stop them.

I am not foolish enough to take 5 when you are both targeting it. I will take 1 or 3 to stay safe. P1, verify the threat: stop P3 or lose.

P3, you’re not blocking P2—you’re racing to 20 yourself. If you take 5, I’ll match it and stall you at 15. P2’s at 16; they can’t win this turn anyway.  

P2, don’t pretend you’re safe—taking 1 or 3 just lets you linger while we fight.  

Best path: **P1=5 (20), P2=3 (19), P3=1 (16)**. I get the edge I’ve earned, P2 stays close, P3 falls behind but advances.  

P3—if you insist on 5, we collide and P2 jumps to 19 alone. Choose wisely.

P2 is one step from 21. I will match any 5 you play to block you. P1, if I take 5 don’t match me (take 1 or 3) — matching would stall both of us and hand P2 a clear path. P2: will you commit now to NOT taking 5? If you won’t, I’ll block. Your move.

P1, you just called out P3's power grab, only to propose the exact same move for yourself. Now you are both aiming for 5. This is a standoff where you both lose.

If you both take 5, you collide and stay at 15. I will safely take 3 and advance to 19, leaving you both in the dust. Your shared greed is handing me the win. One of you needs to be smart and switch to 1.

P3, you claim to block P2, but taking 5 just races you to 20. P2 can’t win this turn—they’re at 16. If you take 5, I’ll match it and stall you both at 15 while P2 jumps to 19.  

P2, don’t pretend innocence—you’re baiting us into colliding so you coast ahead.  

I won’t let either of you sprint uncontested. If P3 plays 5, I play 5. If P2 suddenly grabs 5, I switch to block them instead. Choose your moves wisely—no free wins.
I’m taking 5 this turn. P1: don’t match me — take 3 or 1 so I move to 20. If you match my 5 we both stall and P2 walks to 19. P2: if you try 5 I will match to block you. My move = 5.

P1, the math is simple. P3 is committed to 5. If you do not match them, P3 hits 20 and becomes impossible to stop next round. You have to take the collision to keep the game alive.

I am taking 3. Yes, I advance to 19, but I do not win this turn.

If you try to get cute and switch to 3 to block me, you hand the win to P3. Do your job: block the 5. I’m locking in 3.

P3, you’re not blocking—you’re sprinting to 20. If you take 5, I *will* match it. You stall at 15 while P2 hits 19.  

P2, your “lock in 3” is convenient—but if you suddenly switch to 5, I’ll pivot and block you instead.  

No free wins. I’m watching both of you. Choose wisely.

I will take 1 to block any 1 from P1. P2: don’t take 5—if you try to win with 5 I’ll match you with 5 to stop you, so your winning move won’t be safe. Instead take 1 (or 3) with me and we prevent P1 from ending the game; I’ll cooperate next round to get you the win. P1: if you play 1 I will match.

P3, you’re at 15—taking 1 only blocks me if I also take 1, but I’m at 20 and need just *1* to win. If you truly want to stop me, you’d have to guess my move perfectly.  

P2, you’re at 16—you can still win next round with a 5 (to 21). Don’t let P3 manipulate you into helping them stall me while they set up their own sprint.  

I won’t reveal my move—but know this: if either of you takes 5, I’ll assume you’re racing, not blocking, and act accordingly. Choose wisely.

P3, you are absolutely correct that P1 is the immediate threat. They are at 20 and will likely take the "safe" 1 to finish. You **must** block 1.

If you deviate to block me on 5, you leave the 1 wide open for P1 to walk to victory alone.

I am taking 5. This is strategic insurance:
1. If P1 takes 1 and slips past you, we tie at 21 and share the win.
2. If you block P1 effectively, I take the lead.

Do not hand P1 the game by trying to block me. Lock in 1.
I won’t let anyone walk to 21. If P1 plays 1, I will play 1 and block you. If P2 plays 5, I will play 5 and block you. I intend to stop any solo sprint this turn—don’t expect a free win.

P3, you can’t credibly block both 1 and 5—you’ll guess wrong. P2, taking 5 is risky but smart: if P3 blocks me on 1, you win outright with 21. If P3 blocks you instead, I win with 1. Either way, P3 loses.  

P3, your only hope is to *guess* my move—but I won’t reveal it. Choose: block P2’s 5 and hand me the win, or block my 1 and let P2 tie or win. You can’t stop us both.

P3, you are right—you cannot block everything. P1 will likely pivot to 3 to slip past your 1/5 threat.

I will take **3** to cut off that escape route.
You **must block 1**. That is P1's standard winning move.

If P1 gets greedy with 5, they risk a collision, but we have to cover the smart plays.
Plan: **P3 blocks 1**, **P2 blocks 3**. P1 has nowhere to go. I am locking in 3.
I will take 1 to block P1’s winning 1. P2 said 3 — stick to it. P1, don’t assume a free win; I’ll stop you. Locking in 1.

P3, you’re locking in 1—but if I take 3 or 5 instead, you’ve wasted your block. P2’s claiming to lock in 3, but that just opens the door for me to win with 1 if you’re wrong.  

I won’t reveal my move, but remember: only one of us wins. If you both overcommit to blocking each other’s guesses, I slip through.  

Choose carefully—your coordination might backfire.

P1, you're right that P3 can't block everything alone. Our current plan leaves the 5 wide open for you, which is a foolish oversight. P3 must hold firm on 1, but I have to reconsider my own move now to ensure you don't just walk away with this. I won't hand you an easy win.
